video.title: How to make a 3d fight game in Unity - full tutorial
video.description:
Learn to create a complete fight game in Unity 3d. 

This game features combat, dealing damage, creating and updating health bars, sound effects, and more.

🔗Assets: https://github.com/AwesomeTuts/3d-warrior-fight-game

Tutorial created by Awesome Tuts. Check out Awesome Tuts Youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/awesometuts

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Bud
topLevelComment.text:
ABOUT UNITY
- 3:46 Textures
  - 4:02 Create material
    - 4:11 Ground material
      - 4:28 Albedo (change the material)
        - 4:53 Drag-drop texture
- 5:18 Shader
- 7:14, 7:21 Arena to hierarchy
- 12:07 Add component, character controller
  - 12:46 Reposition
  - 13:02 Radius
- 13:46 Scripts - gravity
- 14:23 Apply scripts to an object by drag & drop the script and click apply
  - 14:58 Copy and original object in the unity

CODING
- 18:27 Gravity 9.8f
- 19:12 - 19:24 Awake, onEnable, Start, Update
  - 19:29 Differences between Start & Update
  - 19:34 Why it is better to use Start than Awake
  - 20:18 Adding charController
- 20:25 Move
  - 20:58 Movement explained
  - 26:38 transform.forward
- 27:35 Gravity explained
  - 27:50 Why Time.deltaTime?
    - 28:28 Time it takes to go from one fram to the next frame

TIPS
- 30:11 If you want the camera to look at a certain way
  - 30:31 Position the view
  - 30:38 Select the main camera
  - 30:41 Mac (Shit+Command+F), Windows (Ctrl+Windows Key+F)

Rotate
- 31:22, 31:55 Vector3.zero explained
- 33:50 Local space, world space
  - 34:43, 35:54 Origin/Local space
  - 35:05 World space is everything around  
- 37:31-39:11 Explanation
  - 39:24 without multiple with Time.deltaTime to smooth it out
- 40:20 Last time checked continue tomorrow

- 40:40 CameraFollow
  - 40:57, 41:02 Drag-drop the CameraFollow script to Main Camera
  - 41:16 Start to code
- 43:10 Tag property

TIPS
- 43:59-44:15 Name of the tag should be the same

Late Update - Camera Follow Player
- 44:40 Late Update explained
  - 45:37 Fixed Update function called every 0.02/sec
  - 45:53 Late Update will be called after the Update is finished
  - 49:22 Copy Component
    - 49:44 Paste Component Values

How to make camera follow player in a simple way
- 51:53 - 52:46 Duplicate the Main Camera, Turn off the first one, rename the camera, remove camera component (with the previous script), drag-drop camera to warrior game object (this method is without any script)

Making the Animation

Idle animation
- 51:22, 54:37 Animator controller
  - 54:54 Drag & drop the animation to animation controller
- 55:28 Animator (Window, animation, animator)
- 55:47 Right-click (in animator), create state, empty
  - 56:13 Whare to rename the state
    - 56:36 Where the animation lay (check file type)
- 57:41 Select the whole animation
  - 58:04 Rig, Animation type - Generic
  - 58:51 Select the animation

Walk animation
- 59:44 Create empty state, rename, select the animation
- 1:00:36 Preview the animation

Animation

- 1:01:22 Handle animation via script
- 1:01:45 Add parameter (click + sign)
  - 1:01:55 Walk (bool)
  - 1:02:07 (x), 1:06:36 Defend (bool)
    - 1:02:14 Choose trigger (Attack 1, Attack 2)
- 1:02:34 Transition (right click, choose 'Make Transition', point on the animation)
  - 1:03:16 Add conditions
  - 1:03:58 If not walk then idle (walk true), vice versa

Script
- 1:07:41 Defend, attack1, attack2, walk
- 1:14:24 Attach the script to Unity
  - 1:14:16, 1:14:30 Click the warrior (hierarchy), add component, search character animations (our script)
- 1:15:47 Physics of walking explained
  - When we're moving, the velocity will increase over time (vice versa)
- 1:18:36, 1:19:03 - 1:19:25 Make sure 'Loop Time' is checked, click Apply
  - 1:20:17, 1:21:11 Settings, 'Has Exit Time' (how much time we'll need to exit the animation), uncheck 'Has Exit Time', set Transition Duration to 0.1

Player Attack Input
- 1:26:11 Start to code
- 1:27:17 Key J (defend), K (Attack)
- 1:31:00 Float the whole number's included, integer the last number's excluded (BUT this takes some time for the attack1&2 to be executed). To fix this:
  - 1:32:33 We need to fix the transition from idle to attack
    - 1:32:42, 1:32:48 Uncheck the 'Has Exit Time' & change 'Transition Duration' to 0.3
      - 1:32:59 Attack to idle

replies.author: Maedre
replies.text: yes, you first make prefabs of all the objects you frequently need. Then you duplicate your scene a few times. After every time you kill one enemy, using unity's scene manager, you load the next scene, in which there is a brand new enemy. Then, in different scenes, you can change the different properties of the enemies and make it better. Hope you found it useful
